doc.field: DM 4 billion deficit for public insurance plans

Federal Health Minister Seehofer and the public health insurance companies foresee the possibility of not increasing premiums in Western Germany until the end of next year. Presenting the semi-annual financial report for the public insurance companies, Seehofer said that, despite a deficit of about DM 4 billion in the first half of 1997, rate increases could be done without, in the middle term. He added, however, that that was assuming the companies continued to cut back expenses. Expenditures for services are down about 1 percent so far this year, while monies coming in have remained constant. Due to the difficult financial situation in Eastern Germany, premium increases could not be ruled out. Several of the large public insurance companies have announced that they would leave the premiums there untouched on the condition that no "solidarity funds" were used to compensate for the deficit in the East.
President Herzog ends official visit in Moscow

Moscow, Russia. Federal President Herzog has ended the official part of his state visit in Russia. Speaking before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Russian Duma, Herzog called on Russians and Germans to quickly expand upon the cooperation already in evidence between the two peoples. Herzog called on the Russian deputies to seek out partnership with the West, and to avoid old-style power politics. He promised Germany's continuing support for democratic reforms in Russia, for the sake of a common future in peace. Herzog thanked Russian President Yeltsin for his hospitality, saying he was met with an "unbelievably heartfelt atmosphere". Following Herzog's appearance, a communist deputy presented him with a resolution, in the name of the majority of Duma members, in support of former East German leader Egon Krenz, who was sentenced to six and a half years' imprisonment last week in Berlin. To finish his visit, Herzog has flown to Samara on the Volga River to take part in celebrations as Sara and Stuttgart are officially named sister cities.
SPD approves initiatives against youth unemployment

The SPD members of the Bundestag have approved two initiatives to fight youth unemployment, at a closed meeting. An Apprenticeship-Financing Law is intended to relieve the financial burden of companies offering apprenticeship positions to a sufficient number of young people. Companies training too few youths, on the other hand, are to be made to pay into the programme. At the same time, the SPD members supported a move to introduce qualification measures for beginning careers.
Rexrodt: Programme for investment and jobs successful

More than a year and a half after presenting a 50-point programme to encourage investment and jobs, Federal Economic Minister Rexrodt has judged it a success. In an interim report which Rexrodt presented to the cabinet today, he indicated that almost all of the planned measures had been realized or at least initiated. The economic upswing is gaining momentum, German companies are more competitive and the long-awaited turn-around in the labour markets is getting closer, according to Rexrodt. The Economic Ministry is projecting 4.2 million unemployed for 1998, however; that is about 100,000 fewer than at present.
Forestry report presented

Natural Resources Minister Borchert has presented his first forestry report. In the future he is to present a general overview of the state of Germany's forests, as well as the forestry and lumber industries, every year. The forestry Damage Report can be expected every November. According to Borchert, a 50 percent increase in tree-cutting in Germany could be undertaken with no threat to the environment.
Amnesty International demands more protection for North African refugees

Human-rights organization Amnesty International has called for more protection for refugees from North Africa and the Middle East. A report issued by the organization states that there are approximately 6.5 million people in flight in the area, as far east as Afghanistan. Amnesty International is criticizing what it considers to be too-harsh laws governing asylum in Germany. As an example, they point to the rejection of nearly all refugees from Algeria, despite on-going terrorist activity by Islamic fundamentalists there.
Krenz remains in custody

Former East German leader Egon Krenz, sentenced to a prison term of six and a half years in connection with fatal shootings at the East-West German border, will remain in custody. A justice spokesman in Berlin announced that the Regional court rejected an appeal to release him from custody, due to concerns that he would flee the country. Now the Supreme Court will have to consider the appeal. Krenz was sentenced to a six and a half year prison term on August 25, and was placed under arrest still in the courtroom.
Serious blow to cigarette mafia

Customs agents in Berlin have dealt a heavy blow to an international smuggling ring. Officials seized 1.6 million illegally imported cigarettes. Two Germans, two Vietnamese, and one Hungarian were arrested. The cigarettes are thought to have been smuggled into Germany from Hungary. A customs agent said that that was a new route. In the last few years, rival groups in the Vietnamese cigarette mafia have been involved in bloody battles, primarily in Berlin, leading to several deaths.
Telephone information soon much more expensive

Telekom directory assistance will jump in price as of next month. As of October 1, getting information, under the new phone number of 11 8 33, will cost DM 1.89 per minute. For the first 30 seconds, the minimum charge will be DM 0.96, even if the call is shorter than that. Beyond the first half-minute, the charge will be 12 Pfennig approximately every 4 seconds. Together with the new rates comes the possibility of a wider range of information than previously, including the address and profession of Telekom customers.
Prison sentences for hate crimes

The chairman of the radical right-wing group "Die Nationalen", Schwerdt (sp?), is on his way to prison for 9 months. The Regional Court in Berlin imposed the sentence with no probation. The 53-year-old was found guilty of hate crimes. A 22-year-old man, also charged in connection with the crime, received a youth sentence of one year and three months, which includes an earlier sentence. The two had penned documents denying the existence of gas chambers in Nazi concentration camps.
Municipalities get financial relief from nursing-care insurance

The introduction of nursing-care insurance will give the municipalities in Baden-Wurttemberg a DM 600 million break in social costs this year. State Social Minster Vetter made the announcement today in Stuttgart. Two years after the introduction of ambulatory nursing-care insurance, about 12,000 people in the Southwest are no longer dependent on social aid, the minister stated. For over a year now, stationary nursing-care has also been financed through the nursing care insurance.
Charges brought against social workers in fatal abuse case

In the case of a two-and-a-half-year-old girl named Jenny, who died due to abuse, an employee of the Luneburg Youth Office and a social worker in Stuttgart are now facing criminal charges. The Public Prosecutor's Office in Stuttgart made the announcement today. Jenny died of a brain haemorrhage from severe abuse in March 1996. Her mother and a couple of her acquaintance were given prison sentences for the death. Now the Public Prosecutor's Office is charging the Youth Office employee with negligence causing death, and the social worker with negligence causing bodily harm, as they did not prevent the abuse.
Lufthansa to be completely privatized

The federal government and Lufthansa have entered the final stretch in the privatization of the airline. The second-largest stock offering in German history (the privatization of Telekom was bigger), it is expected to bring in as much as DM 5 billion - significantly more than anticipated by Federal Finance Minister Waigel. From September 29 to October 9, investors will be able to subscribe for the shares. Beginning October 13, they will be traded on the stock exchange. Private German investors are to be granted a price advantage as well as preferential treatment in the allocation of the shares, according to Waigel.
